questions.text: Identify the organism in Bacitracin sensitivity disk test given below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Streptococcus pyogenes Bacitracin test is used to determine the effect of a small amount of bacitracin (0.04 IU or 0.05 IU not higher) on an organism. Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococci) is inhibited by the small amount of bacitracin in the disk; other beta-hemolytic streptococci usually are not. Some laboratories do not recommend the use of 0.04 U bacitracin disk as Lancefield Group C and G streptococci may occasionally also show susceptibility to bacitracin. PYR reaction can confirm the isolate as S. pyogenes as it is the only beta-hemolytic streptococci that gives positive PYR reaction. Expected results of Bacitracin test: Sensitive: Any zone of inhibition around the disk Resistant: No zone of inhibition Quality control organisms used in Bacitracin test: Test for identifying Streptococcus pyogenes. Positive: Streptococcus pyogenes Negative: Streptococcus agalactiae

questions.text: A child with abdominal pain for 10 days presented to OPD. Stool microscopy was done which showed the egg of Hymenolepis nana in findings. What is the DOC for the disease caused by the given organism?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Praziquantel Hymenolepis nana Also called Dwarf tapeworm Egg is infectious to man Only one host involved Autoinfection seen Armed scolex Larva form called cysticercoid larva Egg smaller, bile non-stained and has polar filament: Diagnostic form Treatment of Cestodes : Praziquantel is the DOC of all cestodes. Intestinal Cestodes - Humans are Definitive Host Tissue Cestodes - Humans are Intermediate Host • Taenia saginata and T. solium • Echinococcus: Causing hydatid disease (liver) • Diphyllobothrium • Taenia solium: Causing cysticercosis’ (CNS) • Hymenolepis nana • Taenia Multiceps: Causing coenurosis • Dipylidium caninum • Spirometra: Sparganosis (muscle)

questions.text: SD plasma kills all lipid enveloped viruses. On SD plasma transfusion, which of the following infection is the likely possibility?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HAV All the above given viruses except HAV are enveloped so the HAV infection will spread even if the SD plasma destroys the lipid envelope of the virus.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: STER-RAD is used for sterilization of surgical equipment. Which of the following is the active agent used in it?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hydrogen peroxide The Sterrad Sterilization System by Advanced Sterilization Products (ASP) exploits the synergism between peroxide and low temperature gas plasma (an excited or ionized gas) to rapidly destroy microorganisms. At the completion of the sterilization process based on this technology, no toxic residues remain on the sterilized items. The technology is particularly suited to the sterilization of heat and moisture sensitive instruments since process temperatures do not exceed about 50°C (140°F) and sterilization occurs in a low moisture environment. Total process time is about 1 hour. The efficacy of the process has been demonstrated against a broad spectrum or microorganisms and on a large number of substrates used in medical instruments. The Sterrad system offers a short cycle (averaging 75 minutes), low temperature and humidity, no aeration requirement, no chemical residues, negligible environmental impact, and wide compatibility with materials. Its drawback is an inability to process liquids, powders, or strong absorbers (e.g., cellulosic)

questions.text: A patient was suffering from hepatorenal syndrome. A urine sample was obtained from the patient and was examined under the microscope. Which of the following techniques is being used to make the organism visible?

options.label: B
options.text: Routine microscopy with negatively stained background

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dark field microscopy Leptospira Leptospira comprises of two species: L. interrogans (pathogenic for humans): Causes leptospirosis or Weil’s disease involving liver and kidney. L. biflexa (saprophyte) Mode of transmission: It is zoonotic, direct human-to-human transmission does not occur. It is transmitted by: Although >100 animals can be infected, important sources of infection are rats, dogs, cattle, and pigs. Indirect contact with water, moist soil, and wet surfaces contaminated with animal urine or direct contact with urine and products of parturition, and placenta of infected animals. The characteristic triad of leptospirosis is jaundice, hemorrhagic manifestations with renal failure. Leptospirosis is also called the disease associated with 3R’s, as important epidemiological determinants for leptospirosis include exposure to rodents, rainfall, and rice fields.

questions.text: Identify the organism which shows effacement and attachment of intestinal cells as shown in the image given below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

EPEC Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) EPEC frequently causes infantile diarrhea (outbreaks) and rarely sporadic diarrhea in adults. It is nontoxigenic and non-invasive Mechanism of diarrhea: Adhesion to cup-like pedestals on the intestinal mucosa, mediated by plasmid coded bundle-forming pili brings about effacement of pili, i.e. A/E lesions (attaching and effacing lesions) on the intestinal epithelium.

questions.text: Identify the organism from the given viral replication cycle:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Influenza Influenza virus The image shows the replication cycle of a virus having a segmented genome. There are certain RNA viruses which have segmented genome, e.g., Influenza virus Characteristic RNA genome of influenza viruses – 7 or 8 segments, negative sense, ssRNA Structure enveloped virus with glycoprotein spikes hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) NP (nucleocapsid protein) Segmented (–) strand RNA gene Other proteins M2-form proton channel in membrane and promote uncoating and viral genome release (inhibited by amantadine and rimantadine) Epidemiology risk: Seronegative, people with underlying cardiorespiratory disease, immunodeficient, and smokers Epidemiology: Type A infects humans, swine, horses, seals, pigs, birds Mostly occurs in winter months. Hemagglutinin (HA) Binds to Sialic acid on epithelial surfaces promoting fusion of envelope - to cell membrane Can agglutinate red blood cells Elicits neutralizing, protective Ab response Responsible for antigenic drift and shift Neuraminidase (NA) Important in releasing mature virus from cells by degrading sialic acid Target for 2 antiviral drugs (Zanamivir and Oseltamivir (Tamiflu)

questions.text: A 7-month old child presented with diarrhea and vomiting for 3 days. Which enterotoxin is most probably responsible for the condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NSP4 Rotavirus non-structural protein 4 (NSP4) is known to function as an intracellular receptor at the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) critical to viral morphogenesis and is the first characterized viral enterotoxin. The association of NSP4 and caveolin-l contributes to NSP4 intracellular trafficking from the ER to the cell surface and speculates that exogenously added NSP4 stimulates signalling molecules located in caveolae micro domains. Rotavirus : Rotaviruses belong to the family Reoviridae; the only RNA virus family to have dsRNA. Surrounded by a triple layered capsid Possess segmented dsRNA (11 segments) Proteins: There are 6-structural viral proteins (VPs) and 6-nonstructural proteins (NSPs) Clinical manifestations: Rotaviruses are the most common cause of diarrheal illness in children. IP is about 1–3 days. It has an abrupt onset, characterized by vomiting followed by watery diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain.

questions.text: Organism most likely associated with VAP:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acinetobacter Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) Pneumonia that develops in a patient who has been on mechanical ventilation >48 hours. 2nd MC hospital-acquired infection among pediatrics and neonatal ICU patients. Rate of pneumonia in pediatric intensive care units (PICU) is lower than in adult intensive care units (ICU). In neonates, the rate of ventilator-associated pneumonia is inversely proportional to birth weight. Children with artificial airways, such as a tracheostomy tube for management of chronic respiratory failure or an endotracheal tube for acute airway management, are at risk for VAP. It is difficult to diagnose VAP. They have classified it into three types: Clinically defined, Pneumonia with laboratory findings, and Pneumonia in immune-compromised patients. Note: Infants and children are usually classified to the first category. Tracheitis Clinical signs of purulent tracheal discharge, fevers, respiratory distress, and the presence of bacteria and white blood cells in the tracheal aspirate without radiological signs of pneumonia. VAP Clinical signs of purulent tracheal discharge, fevers, respiratory distress, and micro-biological signs of the presence of microorganisms along with white blood cells in the tracheal aspirate along with radiological evidence of pneumonia. VAP is typically bacterial and from a single organism. However, polymicrobial infections are increasing. MC organisms are Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and other gram negatives. Artificial airways become colonized with pathogenic bacteria soon after intubation or tracheostomy, and the major pathogens include both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria: S. aureus (including MRSA), aeruginosa, and Klebsiella and Enterobacter species. Patients in an NICU have a risk of Enterococcus species and Group B Streptococcus as well. Other pathogens include the Streptococcus, Enterobacteriaceae, and Acinetobacter species. Anaerobic bacteria are an uncommon cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia but can play a role in polymicrobial infections, particularly when pneumonia is due to aspiration. Nosocomial viruses and fungi are rare causes of pneumonia in immunocompetent hosts. Early pneumonia • Less than 4 days after admission to the hospital • Due to antibiotic-sensitive community-acquired organisms Late pneumonia • More than 4 days • Due to antibiotic-resistant organisms. Study from AIIMS Surgical Department and ICUs shows that the Acinetobacter is nowadays the most common and most specific cause for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

questions.text: All of the following are associated with HHV8 except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

T-cell leukemia Human Herpesvirus-8 Aka Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpes virus (KSHV) Epidemiology: In high prevalence area: HHV-8 is endemic in Africa where it is transmitted by oral secretion. In low prevalence areas such as North America, Asia, Northern Europe, it affects homosexual Less common mode: Organ transplantation, IV drug abuse, and blood transfusion Manifestations: In immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV), HHV-8 causes: Kaposi sarcoma Primary effusion lymphoma (body cavity based lymphomas) Multicentric Cattleman’s disease (Lymphoproliferative disorder of B-cells) However, in immunocompetent host, HHV-8 produces fever and rash Rx: HHV infections respond well to Foscarnet, Ganciclovir, Cidofovir

questions.text: A known HIV patient on antiretroviral therapy presented with diarrhea of six months' duration. Stool microscopy was done in which 10-30 micrometer cysts were seen, Kinyoun stain was positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cystoisospora Comparison of Coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in immunocompromised host Property Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Isospora Infective form Sporulated oocyst • Thick-walled oocyst (80%) by contaminated food and water. • Thin-walled (20%) Autoinfection Sporulated oocyst (Contaminated food and water) Sporulated oocyst (Contaminated food and water) Sporulated oocyst 4–6 μm, round, contains four sporozoite 8–12 μm, round, contains 2 sporocyst each having two sporozoite 23–36 μm, contains 2 sporocyst, each having four sporozoite Acid fastness Detection limit >50,000 oocyst/ml stool Uniformly acid fast Variable acid fast Uniformly acid fast Autofluorescence No, but can be stained with fluorescent dye Autofluorescence + Autofluorescence +/– Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cells (enterocytes) Occurs in soil (environment) Occurs in soil (environment) Diagnostic form Sporulated oocyst Unsporulated oocyst Unsporulated oocyst Autoinfection Seen Not seen Not seen Treatment Nitazoxanide Cotrimoxazole Cotrimoxazole Outbreaks Common Common Less

Table:

#MANTRA Cryptosporidium parvum Cyclospora cayetanensis Isospora belli Causes cryptosporidiosis Causes cyclosporiasis Causes isosporiasis Geog. Distribution: worldwide Parasite takes the shape of oocyst containing sporozoites Man is infected by ingestion of the sporulated oocyst

questions.text: γδ T cell is associated with:

options.label: D
options.text: First line defense against bacterial peptides

questions.correct_answer: D. First line defense against bacterial peptides
questions.explanation:
Solution:

First line defense against bacterial peptides They constitute 5% of total T cells. They express gamma-delta chains of TCR; instead of alpha-beta chains present on the majority of the T cells. γδ TCR have a limited diversity. AU: Should these points be set at second level list 60%: CD4– and CD8– 30%: CD8+ They do not require antigen processing and MHC presentation of peptides. They are considered as part of innate immunity. They are usually found in the gut mucosa as intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs). The function of ϒδT cells is not known; they may encounter the lipid antigens that enter through the intestinal mucosa.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of dysphagia. On UGI endoscopy, a diagnosis of esophageal candidiasis was made. The organism obtained from the sample was cultured on a specialized media and the below findings were visible on microscopy of the culture. What phenomenon is shown below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Germ tube formation The image shows germ tube formation or the Reynolds Braude phenomenon which is classically demonstrated by only two species of Candida: C. albicans and C. dubliniensis. If a few colonies of either of these are added to the serum and incubated at 37 degrees for 2 hours, germ tubes emerge from the yeast cells. Laboratory diagnosis: Direct microscopy: Gram-positive oval budding yeast cells (4–6 micron size) with pseudo hyphae. Culture on SDA: Colonies are described as creamy white, smooth, and pasty with typical yeasty odor.

Extraedge:

Pseudo hyphae True hyphae Septa Constricted No constriction Origin of branches Constricted and septate No constriction, no septum present Grows by Budding Apical elongation

questions.text: In which of the following, viral load done by real time PCR is of no role in investigative procedures?

options.label: A
options.text: Person with hepatitis B on tenofovir therapy

options.label: C
options.text: BK virus in patient of allograft renal transplant

options.label: D
options.text: CMV PCR in blood of patient of liver transplant

questions.explanation:
Solution:

HSV causing temporal encephalitis The question simply asks in which of the given conditions calculation of viral load is not required. In HSV causing temporal encephalitis the role of PCR is just to detect HSV DNA and make a diagnosis of the disease. There is no role of detection of the viral load copies in the management or diagnosis of the disease. Whereas in the other 3 conditions, the estimation of viral load is an important part of the management of the diseases and helps predict the response to the treatment.
